lens.book_chapters: Part 2: Chapters 5-7 — Ch 5: Give Responsibility for Disruptive Technologies to Organizations Whose Customers Need Them; Ch 6: Match the Size of the Organization to the Size of the Market; Ch 7: Discovering New and Emerging Markets
lens.lens_summary: Zillow's resource allocation processes, margin-driven values, and growth-rate requirements structurally prevent it from pursuing the small, undefined mid-term shared housing market — its customers (buyers/sellers/long-term renters) control its investment patterns, its size demands billion-dollar markets, and its planning processes cannot discover a market that doesn't yet exist.

competitor_overview.primary_strength: Comprehensive real estate search with Zestimate home valuations, massive listing inventory, and brand trust for buying/selling/long-term renting — do NOT compete here
competitor_overview.business_model: Premier Agent advertising (real estate agents pay for leads from home buyers/sellers), rental listing fees, mortgage origination fees, and Zillow Home Loans. Revenue depends on high-value, high-margin transactions: home sales averaging $350K+ and long-term leases at $1,500+/month. Their cost structure requires these margins to sustain operations.
competitor_overview.user_base: Home buyers researching properties (largest segment), home sellers comparing values, long-term renters searching apartments, real estate agents purchasing leads, and mortgage seekers. Almost entirely individuals engaged in traditional, high-stakes real estate transactions. Zero presence among mid-term flexible housing seekers, traveling professionals, or shared-space users.
competitor_overview.brand_perception: Trusted and authoritative for property data and home values. Users see Zillow as the 'Google of real estate' — the default starting point for any property search. However, brand perception is transactional and impersonal: users come for data, not for community or relationship-building. There is no emotional connection or trust in Zillow for living arrangement negotiations.

discovery.what_they_do: Zillow's discovery is dominated by SEO, TV advertising, and word-of-mouth brand recognition. Users arrive knowing they want to buy, sell, or rent long-term. The homepage immediately segments users into Buy, Rent, Sell, and Home Loans. Discovery is entirely self-directed — users must already know what category they fall into. There is no discovery path for someone who needs housing for 2-4 months, wants to share a space part-time, or has a non-traditional housing need.
discovery.framework_analysis: Christensen's Ch 5 resource dependence theory explains exactly why Zillow's discovery phase serves only existing customers. The resource allocation process at Zillow — what gets funded, what gets built, what gets marketed — is controlled by the customers who provide revenue: home buyers generating agent leads, and long-term renters clicking on listings. These customers have zero demand for mid-term shared housing discovery. Per Christensen: 'Good resource allocation processes are designed to weed out proposals that customers don't want.' Any Zillow product manager proposing a 'discover mid-term shared housing' feature would have their proposal killed by the same rational processes that make Zillow successful, because no existing Zillow customer is asking for it.
discovery.what_nobody_in_category_does: Nobody in the real estate category has built a discovery experience for people who don't yet know they need mid-term shared housing. The entire category assumes users arrive with a pre-formed intent (buy, rent, sell). There is no discovery flow for the traveling nurse who just got a 13-week assignment, the consultant who works in another city Tuesday-Thursday, or the person going through a divorce who needs somewhere to stay 3 nights a week. These users don't even know to search on Zillow — the category has never tried to reach them or name their need.

evidence.observation: Christensen demonstrates that 'it is a company's customers who effectively control what it can and cannot do' through the resource allocation process. Non-executive participants decide which projects to champion based on what they believe serves the company's most profitable customers.
evidence.framework_interpretation: Zillow's product teams, marketers, and engineers are incentivized to build features that serve home buyers and long-term renters — because those are the customers generating revenue. A discovery flow for mid-term housing would never survive Zillow's internal resource allocation process. The people who would need to champion it can't justify it to their managers, because the customers who pay the bills don't want it.

evidence.observation: Zillow's primary navigation offers exactly four paths: Buy, Rent, Sell, Home Loans. There is no 'Shared Housing', 'Mid-Term Stay', or 'Flexible Living' category. The entire information architecture assumes traditional real estate transactions.
evidence.framework_interpretation: This is the UX manifestation of resource dependence. The navigation reflects what Zillow's profitable customers need. Adding a fifth category for a tiny, undefined market would dilute focus on the revenue-generating paths. Per Christensen, the organization's 'processes and values constitute disabilities' — Zillow's values (high-margin transactions) and processes (data-driven product prioritization based on existing user demand) make it structurally incapable of adding this path.

search.what_they_do: Zillow's search is a map-based interface with powerful filters: price range, bedrooms, bathrooms, square footage, home type, lot size, year built, HOA fees, parking, and dozens more. For rentals, filters include move-in date, lease length, pet policy, and laundry. The search is optimized for a binary outcome: does this property match my long-term living criteria? Results are sorted by relevance, price, or newest. Saved searches trigger email alerts for new listings.
search.framework_analysis: Zillow's search excellence is a direct product of what Christensen calls sustaining innovation — incremental improvements to serve existing customers better. Every filter, every sort option, every map interaction was built because existing customers (buyers and long-term renters) demanded it. Per Ch 6: 'the firms that led in developing and introducing the new technology were the companies that had led in the old technology' for sustaining innovations. Zillow is world-class at sustaining search innovation for traditional real estate. But this very excellence creates the disability Christensen describes: 'a process that defines a capability in executing a certain task concurrently defines disabilities in executing other tasks.'
search.what_nobody_in_category_does: Nobody in real estate search lets you search by schedule compatibility. Mid-term shared housing requires entirely different search dimensions: Which nights of the week is this space available? Can I stay Tuesday-Thursday every week for 16 weeks? Is the host's lifestyle compatible with mine (quiet hours, work schedule, cleanliness standards)? Does the commute work for my Tuesday office days? These are not filters that exist anywhere in the real estate search category — because the category has never conceived of housing as a time-shared, relationship-dependent arrangement.

evidence.source: Ch 6: Leadership in Disruptive Technologies Creates Enormous Value
evidence.observation: Christensen's data shows that 37% of firms entering emerging markets succeeded vs only 6% entering established markets. The firms that led in disruptive technology generated $1.9 billion average revenue vs $64.5 million for followers. But large firms consistently choose the 'safe' established-market approach.
evidence.framework_interpretation: Zillow will never lead in building mid-term housing search because its size demands the 'safe' bet of improving existing search for its massive buyer/renter base. The $800M+ in new revenue Zillow needs annually to maintain growth cannot come from mid-term shared housing search — a market that might generate $50M total in its first years. This is precisely the trap Christensen describes: 'small markets don't solve the growth problems of big companies.'

evidence.observation: Zillow rental search assumes: one tenant, one unit, one lease term (typically 12 months), one move-in date. There is no concept of partial-week occupancy, shared space with a host, negotiable duration, or schedule-based matching. The entire search paradigm is built around the traditional landlord-tenant model.
evidence.framework_interpretation: This search paradigm is what Christensen would call a 'process' that has become a 'disability.' Zillow's search processes were designed and evolved to match people with whole apartments for year-long leases. Repurposing these processes for shared mid-term housing would require fundamentally different data models, different matching algorithms, and different UI patterns — but the processes 'are established so that employees perform recurrent tasks in a consistent way' and 'are meant not to change.'

listing_evaluation.what_they_do: Zillow's listing pages are data-rich: professional photos (often 30-50+), 3D Home tours via Matterport, floor plans, detailed property facts, Zestimate values, price history, tax history, neighborhood data, school ratings, nearby comparable sales, commute time calculator, and cost-of-living estimates. For rentals: unit photos, amenity lists, pet policies, parking info, and application links. The experience is designed for independent evaluation — the user consumes information alone and makes a decision without interacting with the other party.
listing_evaluation.framework_analysis: Per Ch 5, Zillow's listing evaluation is a product of its value network. In Zillow's network, the 'customer' evaluating a listing is making a high-stakes, largely independent decision (buying a $400K house or signing a 12-month lease). The listing page is optimized for this: maximum data density, objective metrics, zero relationship context. Christensen's Woolworth vs. Kresge case (Ch 5) shows that companies cannot maintain 'two models for how to make money within a single organization.' Zillow's listing evaluation model — impersonal, data-dense, transaction-focused — is structurally incompatible with shared housing evaluation, which requires relationship assessment, lifestyle compatibility, and trust-building.
listing_evaluation.what_nobody_in_category_does: Nobody in the category shows you what it would be like to live WITH someone. Mid-term shared housing isn't just about the space — it's about the person sharing it. No listing platform in real estate shows host lifestyle patterns, communication style, house rules philosophy, guest reviews of the host's hospitality, or compatibility indicators. The entire category treats housing as a product to be evaluated on specs, not as a relationship to be entered. This is the mediocre coffee — nobody has even attempted to make the human compatibility layer of housing evaluation great.

evidence.source: Ch 5: Woolworth vs. Kresge case study
evidence.observation: Christensen details how Woolworth tried to run discount retailing (Woolco) within its variety store organization. Despite initial separate administration, the organizations were consolidated for 'efficiency.' Woolco's margins were pulled up to match Woolworth's 33% — destroying its discount positioning. 'Two models for how to make money cannot peacefully coexist within a single organization.'
evidence.framework_interpretation: If Zillow tried to add shared-housing listing evaluation alongside its existing listing pages, the same consolidation pressure would occur. The shared housing listing would be forced to conform to Zillow's existing listing template — heavy on property data, light on human compatibility — because that's what Zillow's processes and values know how to produce. The relationship-centric evaluation experience that shared housing demands would be rationalized away in favor of the 'more efficient' standard listing format.

evidence.observation: Zillow listing pages have zero human presence beyond the listing agent's contact card. There is no host profile, no personality description, no lifestyle indicators, no communication style signals, no reviews from previous tenants about the landlord as a person. The property is presented as an object, completely decoupled from the humans involved.
evidence.framework_interpretation: In Zillow's value network, this dehumanization is a feature, not a bug — buyers and long-term renters want objective property data, not personality assessments of the seller. But for mid-term shared housing, where you're choosing a person to share space with, this is a catastrophic gap. Zillow cannot add this human layer without fundamentally changing what a 'listing' means — and per Christensen, its processes define what a listing is in ways that 'are meant not to change.'

booking_proposal.what_they_do: Zillow's 'booking' equivalent varies by transaction type. For purchases: users click 'Contact Agent' to connect with a buyer's agent, initiating an offline process. For rentals: users click 'Apply' which redirects to the property management company's application portal (often a third party like RentCafe or AppFolio). The process is one-directional: the applicant submits; the landlord accepts or rejects. There is no negotiation interface, no term customization, and no back-and-forth proposal mechanism within Zillow itself. Zillow is a lead-generation funnel, not a transaction platform for rentals.
booking_proposal.framework_analysis: This is where Christensen's Ch 7 insight about 'plans for learning vs. plans for execution' becomes relevant. Zillow's booking/application process was designed through the same market-research-driven planning that Christensen criticizes: they studied what existing rental customers wanted (easy applications, fast responses) and built exactly that. But Christensen shows that 'the same analytical and decision-making processes learned in the school of sustaining innovation are applied to enabling or disruptive technologies, the effect on the company can be paralyzing.' Zillow's process demands 'crisply quantified information when none exists' — you can't A/B test a negotiation feature for a market that doesn't use Zillow. Their booking process is adequate for long-term rentals but fundamentally cannot support the bilateral negotiation that shared housing requires.
booking_proposal.what_nobody_in_category_does: Nobody in the real estate category has built a structured negotiation flow between two individuals who will share space. The entire category treats booking as a one-way application: tenant applies, landlord approves. There is no concept of proposal and counter-proposal on terms like which nights, what duration, what price per night, what house rules. The negotiation layer — where two humans collaboratively define the terms of a shared living arrangement — simply does not exist anywhere in real estate. It's not broken; it was never built.

evidence.source: Ch 7: Plans to Learn versus Plans to Execute
evidence.observation: Christensen argues that 'in disruptive situations, action must be taken before careful plans are made' and that strategies 'should be plans for learning and discovery rather than plans for execution.' He demonstrates through Honda's motorcycle entry and Intel's microprocessor discovery that the winning application is unknowable in advance.
evidence.framework_interpretation: The negotiation UX that mid-term shared housing needs cannot be designed through Zillow's standard product process of customer research, requirements gathering, and phased development. The use cases are too novel: how do two strangers negotiate which nights of the week one will sleep in the other's spare room? This requires the 'agnostic marketing' Christensen advocates — launching something minimal and learning from how people actually use it. Zillow's execution-oriented planning processes make this approach impossible at their scale.

evidence.observation: Clicking 'Apply' on a Zillow rental listing redirects to a third-party application portal. The user fills out income verification, employment history, references, and credit check authorization. It's a formal, one-directional credentialing process. There is no messaging with the landlord before applying, no term negotiation, and no ability to propose modified terms.
evidence.framework_interpretation: Zillow has outsourced the actual transaction to third parties — evidence that even the rental transaction itself is not Zillow's core business. Their value is in lead generation and search, not in facilitating the relationship between parties. Building a bilateral negotiation platform would require entirely new processes that don't exist within Zillow, and per Christensen's RPV framework, 'the very mechanisms through which organizations create value are intrinsically inimical to change.'

communication.what_they_do: Zillow offers minimal direct communication features. For home purchases, communication happens through agents (offline). For rentals, some listings allow a 'Message' button that sends an inquiry to the property manager. There is no persistent messaging thread, no structured communication tools, and no in-app communication between tenants and landlords after lease signing. Zillow's role ends at lead generation — ongoing communication between housing parties is not part of their product.
communication.framework_analysis: Christensen's Ch 5 explains this through the lens of resource dependence and value networks. In Zillow's value network, the customer (home buyer) communicates through their agent, and the landlord communicates through their property manager. The intermediary model is how Zillow's ecosystem makes money — agents and property managers are Zillow's paying customers. Building direct communication between end parties would disintermediate Zillow's actual revenue sources. Per Christensen: 'companies' freedom of action is limited to satisfying the needs of those entities outside the firm that give it the resources it needs to survive.' Zillow's paying customers (agents, property managers) don't want Zillow to enable direct party-to-party communication.
communication.what_nobody_in_category_does: Nobody in real estate has built communication tools designed for the ongoing rhythm of shared living. Mid-term shared housing requires arrival notifications ('I'm on my way'), cleaning verification photos, schedule coordination ('I need to swap Thursday for Friday this week'), and house-rule-adjacent messaging. These are communication patterns borrowed from hospitality, not real estate. The entire real estate category views communication as a pre-transaction function (inquiry and application) rather than an ongoing operational necessity throughout the living arrangement.

evidence.source: Ch 5: DEC and the Personal Computer
evidence.observation: Christensen shows how DEC tried four times to enter the PC market from within its mainstream organization. Each time, 'those who made the day-to-day resource allocation decisions in the company never saw the sense in investing the necessary money, time, and energy in low-margin products that their customers didn't want.'
evidence.framework_interpretation: Zillow building a communication platform for shared housing tenants would be the equivalent of DEC building PCs: technically simple, but organizationally impossible. Zillow's employees, aligned with high-margin agent-lead and advertising businesses, would never allocate resources to a messaging tool for a tiny, non-monetized user segment. The few engineers who might champion it would find their career prospects better served by improving the core search or agent tools.

evidence.observation: After a user finds a rental on Zillow and signs a lease (via a third-party platform), Zillow provides zero ongoing tools. No messaging, no payment tracking, no maintenance requests, no communication with the landlord. The relationship between Zillow and the renter effectively ends at the point of lead conversion.
evidence.framework_interpretation: This total absence of post-transaction tools reveals Zillow's value network boundary. Per Christensen, companies are embedded in value networks that define what they consider valuable. Zillow's value network ends at the transaction moment. Everything after — the actual experience of living somewhere — is outside its value network. For shared housing, where communication IS the product experience, this is not a gap that can be patched. It would require Zillow to redefine its entire value network.

active_stay.what_they_do: Zillow has zero presence during the active stay period. Once a user has found and secured housing through Zillow's search, Zillow's product involvement ends completely. There are no stay management tools, no date flexibility features, no payment tracking, no house manual integration, and no dispute resolution. Active stay management is entirely outside Zillow's product scope.
active_stay.framework_analysis: This absence is the most powerful illustration of Christensen's Ch 6 argument. Zillow is a $7B+ revenue company that needs hundreds of millions in new revenue annually to maintain growth. The active-stay management market for mid-term shared housing is, generously, a $50-100M total addressable market in its earliest years. Per Christensen: 'Because growing companies need to add increasingly large chunks of new revenue each year just to maintain their desired rate of growth, it becomes less and less possible that small markets can be viable as vehicles through which to find these chunks of revenue.' Active stay management for shared housing is simply too small for Zillow to notice, let alone invest in. This is not a strategic oversight — it is a mathematical impossibility given Zillow's size.
active_stay.what_nobody_in_category_does: Nobody in the real estate category manages the ongoing cadence of a shared living arrangement: date changes mid-lease, per-night stay tracking, arrival/departure coordination, cleaning verification between stays, payment adjustment for modified schedules. Even Airbnb, which manages short-term stays, doesn't handle the recurring weekly rhythm of a months-long shared arrangement where the same guest returns every Tuesday. This is genuinely uncharted territory — a product category that exists between traditional property management and hospitality management, and nobody has built for it.

evidence.observation: Christensen demonstrates how Apple's Newton PDA sold 140,000 units in its first two years — three times more than the Apple II at the same stage — but was viewed as a failure because '$5 billion Apple needed big chunks of revenue.' The Newton 'made hardly a dent in Apple's need for new growth.'
evidence.framework_interpretation: Even if Zillow built a stay-management tool and it performed well by startup standards (say, 10,000 active shared-housing arrangements), it would be invisible against Zillow's hundreds of millions of monthly users and billions in revenue. The same rational processes that correctly prioritize improvements to home search would correctly deprioritize stay management. Per Christensen, 'small markets cannot satisfy the near-term growth requirements of big organizations' — this is not bad management, it is structural reality.

evidence.source: Industry pattern: real estate vs. hospitality
evidence.observation: The real estate industry has historically defined its product as the transaction (finding, signing) rather than the experience (living). Property management companies handle ongoing tenancy, but they manage buildings, not individual room-sharing arrangements. Hospitality platforms manage stays, but for short-term, not recurring mid-term patterns.
evidence.framework_interpretation: This gap between real estate and hospitality is precisely the kind of 'emerging value network' that Christensen describes in Ch 6 — a market that doesn't fit neatly into any existing industry's value network. The firms that will capture this market will be those 'small enough to get excited about small-market opportunities,' not the Zillows of the world whose size demands billion-dollar markets.

post_stay.what_they_do: Zillow has no post-stay or post-lease experience. There is no review system for landlords or tenants, no stay quality feedback mechanism, no documentation of the housing experience. When a lease ends, the user's relationship with Zillow for that transaction is simply over. Zillow does not track or surface historical rental experiences.
post_stay.framework_analysis: Christensen's Ch 7 insight about 'agnostic marketing' and discovering markets through use, not research, applies directly here. The post-stay review experience for shared housing is an example of a product feature whose value 'cannot be analyzed' because 'markets that do not exist cannot be analyzed.' Zillow could not validate the ROI of a shared-housing review system through its standard market research processes, because the users who would need it don't exist on the platform. Per Christensen, 'experts' forecasts will always be wrong' for disruptive products — Zillow's data-driven product processes would forecast zero demand for post-stay reviews, because zero shared-housing stays happen on Zillow.
post_stay.what_nobody_in_category_does: Nobody in real estate has built a review system calibrated to shared living. Airbnb has host/guest reviews, but for one-off stays, not ongoing relationships. No platform captures the nuance of reviewing someone you shared space with weekly for four months: was their communication consistent? Did they respect the schedule? Were house rules followed across dozens of stays? The trust signals needed for mid-term shared housing are fundamentally different from both hotel reviews and rental reviews — they're about the reliability and compatibility of a long-term arrangement, not a single experience.

evidence.observation: Honda's executives entered North America planning to sell large highway motorcycles. They completely failed. The winning product — small dirt bikes — was discovered accidentally when employees used personal Supercubs on weekends and neighbors asked where to buy them. 'Honda's idea about how to enter the North American motorcycle market was wrong, but the company didn't deplete its resources pursuing its big-bike strategy.'
evidence.framework_interpretation: The post-stay experience for shared housing will likely be discovered the same way — through actual use, not through planning. The review patterns, trust signals, and feedback mechanisms that matter will only emerge after hundreds of real shared-housing stays. Zillow's planning-oriented product process, which 'demands crisply quantified information when none exists,' cannot discover these features. Only a small company operating in the market, learning from each stay, can iterate toward the right post-stay experience.

evidence.observation: Zillow has reviews for real estate agents (via Zillow Premier Agent) but no reviews for landlords, tenants, or rental experiences. The review system is designed to help Zillow's paying customers (agents) build credibility, not to help renters evaluate landlords.
evidence.framework_interpretation: This confirms Christensen's resource dependence: Zillow's review system serves the entities that provide revenue (agents), not the end users. Building a review system for shared-housing hosts and guests would serve a non-paying user segment in a non-existent market — doubly impossible within Zillow's value structure.

retention.what_they_do: Zillow's retention strategy is search-frequency based: Saved Homes, Price Drop alerts, Zestimate tracking for homeowners, and email marketing for future transactions. For renters, retention is near-zero — once a lease is signed, Zillow has no ongoing engagement mechanism until the user needs to search again (typically 12+ months later). Zillow's retention model assumes infrequent, high-value transactions, not ongoing platform engagement.
retention.framework_analysis: Christensen's Ch 5 HP LaserJet/InkJet case study is instructive here. HP succeeded with its disruptive ink-jet printer by 'creating a completely autonomous organizational unit, located in Vancouver, Washington, with responsibility for making the ink-jet printer a success.' The key insight: HP let the two businesses compete against each other. Zillow would need to do the same — create an autonomous unit for shared housing with its own retention model — but unlike HP, Zillow has no internal champion who sees shared housing as an existential threat requiring autonomous investment. The disruptive threat to Zillow comes from a completely different market (mid-term shared housing) that Zillow's executives don't even perceive as related to their business.
retention.what_nobody_in_category_does: Nobody in real estate has built retention around recurring housing needs. Mid-term shared housing generates natural retention: a traveling nurse completes a 13-week assignment, then gets another one in a different city. A consultant finishes one project, starts another. The same users need the platform repeatedly on 3-6 month cycles, not 12-month cycles. This creates a retention dynamic more like a SaaS tool than a real estate platform — regular, habitual use rather than episodic high-stakes transactions. No real estate platform has designed for this recurring-use pattern.

evidence.source: Ch 5: HP LaserJet vs. InkJet autonomous organization
evidence.observation: HP created a completely separate organization in Vancouver, WA to pursue the disruptive ink-jet printer, letting it compete with the established LaserJet division in Boise, ID. 'Had HP not set up its ink-jet business as a separate organization, the ink-jet technology would probably have languished within the mainstream laser jet business.'
evidence.framework_interpretation: Zillow would need to create a completely separate organization — different brand, different team, different metrics, different cost structure — to pursue shared housing. The retention model for this separate org would look nothing like Zillow's: instead of 'come back when you need to move,' it would be 'manage your next 13-week assignment.' But per Christensen, the probability of Zillow choosing this spin-out strategy is extremely low, because executives don't perceive mid-term shared housing as a threat to their core real estate business. Unlike HP, which could see ink-jet cannibalizing laser-jet, Zillow cannot see shared housing cannibalizing home search.

evidence.observation: Zillow's most engaged users are homeowners tracking their Zestimate and prospective buyers doing research. Renters are the least engaged segment — they search intensely for 2-4 weeks, find a place, and disappear for 12 months. There is no product mechanism to keep renters engaged between lease cycles.
evidence.framework_interpretation: Zillow's retention is architecturally designed for infrequent use. The company's values — shaped by high-value, low-frequency transactions — cannot accommodate a retention model based on frequent, lower-value engagement. Per Christensen's RPV framework, 'values that focus an organization's priorities on high-margin products cannot simultaneously focus priorities on low-margin products.' Shared housing's frequent-engagement retention model is incompatible with Zillow's values.

split_lease_phase_mapping.discovery: Phase 1 (Host Creates a Listing — Homepage) and Phase 2 (Guest finds listing — Homepage/Listing Detail). Split Lease's discovery serves both hosts listing shared spaces and guests seeking flexible arrangements — two personas Zillow doesn't address.
split_lease_phase_mapping.search: Phase 2 (Guest navigates to Host's listing — Listing Detail Page). Split Lease's search-equivalent includes schedule-based parameters (nights of the week, duration in weeks) that have no analog in Zillow's search.
split_lease_phase_mapping.listing_evaluation: Phase 2 (Listing Detail Page — nightly rate, 4-week rent, features, duration selector, day-of-week selection). Split Lease's listing evaluation includes human compatibility signals and flexible term configuration that Zillow's property-data-focused listings cannot provide.
split_lease_phase_mapping.booking_proposal: Phase 2 (Guest clicks Create Proposal — Proposal Summary) and Phase 3 (Host Reviews/Counters — Edit Proposal Terms). Split Lease's bilateral negotiation flow (proposal, counter-proposal, term modification) has zero equivalent in Zillow's one-directional application process.
split_lease_phase_mapping.communication: Phase 5 (Host-Guest Communication — arrival notifications, cleaning photos, general messaging). Split Lease's ongoing communication tools for active shared-living arrangements are completely absent from Zillow.
split_lease_phase_mapping.active_stay: Phase 5 (Leases page, Stays Manager, Date Change Tool). Split Lease's date add/remove/swap functionality and per-stay management have no equivalent in any real estate platform including Zillow.
split_lease_phase_mapping.post_stay: Phase 5 (Stay Review — Guest reviews Host/space, Host reviews Guest). Split Lease's dual-review system for shared living experiences has no equivalent in Zillow's agent-only review system.
split_lease_phase_mapping.retention: Phase 5 (Leases page as central hub for active and past agreements). Split Lease's retention is built around ongoing lease management and recurring housing needs, contrasting with Zillow's episodic search-then-disappear model.

category_blind_spots.blind_spot: The entire real estate category has no concept of housing-as-a-schedule. Every platform assumes housing is a binary state (you live here or you don't), never a time-shared arrangement where someone occupies space on specific days of the week for a defined multi-week period.
category_blind_spots.why_nobody_tries: Christensen's Ch 6 explains this precisely: 'small, emerging markets cannot solve the near-term growth and profit requirements of large companies.' Every major real estate platform (Zillow, Redfin, Apartments.com, Realtor.com) is large enough that the mid-term shared housing market is mathematically irrelevant to their growth targets. They literally cannot afford to care about it. And smaller proptech startups have focused on sustaining innovations (better search, better applications, better payments) rather than disruptive ones, because per Ch 6, '65 percent of the companies entering the disk drive industry attempted to do so in an established, rather than emerging market.'
category_blind_spots.framework_insight: Per Christensen Ch 5: 'the patterns of innovation in a company will mirror quite closely the patterns in which resources are allocated.' Real estate companies allocate resources to housing-as-transaction (buying, selling, leasing) because that's where revenue comes from. Housing-as-a-schedule generates no revenue for any existing platform, so no resources are allocated to it, so no innovation occurs. This is the resource dependence trap: the market for schedule-based housing exists (traveling professionals, multi-locality workers, transitional housing seekers), but no existing company's customers are asking for it.

category_blind_spots.blind_spot: No real estate platform facilitates relationship formation between co-habitants. The entire category treats the other party in a housing arrangement as an obstacle to be processed (background checked, credit scored, references verified) rather than a human to be understood, evaluated for compatibility, and negotiated with.
category_blind_spots.why_nobody_tries: The real estate category's business model depends on intermediaries (agents, property managers) who capture value by standing between the two parties. Building direct relationship tools between housing parties would disintermediate the intermediaries who are the platforms' paying customers. Per Christensen Ch 5: 'it is forces outside the organization, rather than the managers within it, that dictate the company's course.' The paying customers (agents, PMs) dictate that the product keeps parties separated and mediated.
category_blind_spots.framework_insight: Christensen's Ch 5 resource dependence theory predicts that real estate platforms will continue to build features that serve intermediaries (agent CRM tools, PM application processing, lead scoring) rather than features that connect end parties directly. The structural incentive is to keep parties dependent on intermediaries. For shared housing, where there IS no intermediary (no agent represents you in finding a roommate for Tuesday nights), the entire intermediary-centric product architecture is useless. This is the 'different value network' Christensen describes — shared housing exists in a value network where the end parties ARE the entire transaction, and no existing real estate platform operates in this network.

category_blind_spots.blind_spot: No platform in real estate provides ongoing stay management tools — the ability to modify dates, track per-stay cleaning, manage arrivals/departures, and adjust terms within an active arrangement. Property management software manages buildings, not individual shared-living relationships.
category_blind_spots.why_nobody_tries: Per Christensen Ch 7: 'markets that do not exist cannot be analyzed.' Stay management for mid-term shared housing is an unknowable market — you cannot forecast its size, define its features, or validate its ROI through existing market research methods. Every large real estate company's product development process, as Christensen describes, 'demands crisply quantified information when none exists, accurate estimates of financial returns when neither revenues nor costs can be known.' No product manager at Zillow, Airbnb, or any property management company can write a product requirements document for stay management in mid-term shared housing, because the use cases haven't been discovered yet.
category_blind_spots.framework_insight: Christensen's Ch 7 concept of 'agnostic marketing' — operating 'under an explicit assumption that no one can know whether, how, or in what quantities a disruptive product can or will be used before they have experience using it' — is the only viable approach to building stay management. The features that matter will only emerge from observing real shared-housing arrangements in action. HP's Kittyhawk team 'conceded in retrospect that their most serious mistake was to act as if their forecasts about the market were right, rather than as if they were wrong.' The stay management product must be built through discovery-driven iteration, not through market research and planning.

category_blind_spots.blind_spot: The entire real estate category lacks a trust and reputation system calibrated to ongoing shared-living relationships. Hotel reviews measure single stays. Apartment reviews measure buildings. Agent reviews measure transaction service. Nobody measures the accumulated trust of repeated shared-space interactions over months.
category_blind_spots.why_nobody_tries: Building a shared-living trust system requires the underlying platform to first exist and generate enough stays to produce meaningful review data. It's a chicken-and-egg problem compounded by what Christensen Ch 7 calls the unknowability of disruptive markets: you can't design the trust system until you've observed what trust signals actually matter in shared housing (which nobody has). Per Christensen, the successful approach is Honda-style: enter the market, observe what happens, and discover the trust patterns through use rather than research.
category_blind_spots.framework_insight: Christensen Ch 7: 'the vast majority of successful new business ventures abandoned their original business strategies when they began implementing their initial plans and learned what would and would not work in the market.' The trust system for shared housing will likely look nothing like what anyone would design from first principles. The signals that matter — cleaning photo consistency, schedule reliability, communication response time over 16 weeks — can only be discovered through actual platform operation. Per Christensen, 'guessing the right strategy at the outset isn't nearly as important to success as conserving enough resources so that new business initiatives get a second or third stab at getting it right.'

category_blind_spots.blind_spot: No real estate platform supports bilateral term negotiation. Every platform in the category uses a take-it-or-leave-it model: the landlord sets terms, the tenant applies, and the landlord accepts or rejects. The concept of structured counter-proposals — where either party can modify duration, pricing, schedule, or house rules — does not exist.
category_blind_spots.why_nobody_tries: Bilateral negotiation adds complexity that reduces conversion rates in traditional real estate, where speed-to-lease is the key metric. Property managers want applications processed quickly, not negotiated over. Per Christensen Ch 5, the resource allocation process at real estate platforms prioritizes features that accelerate the existing transaction flow (faster applications, instant approvals, auto-scheduling tours), not features that slow it down with negotiation. The 'good resource allocation processes are designed to weed out proposals that customers don't want' — and existing real estate customers don't want negotiation friction.
category_blind_spots.framework_insight: In Christensen's framework, the negotiation layer is a classic disruptive feature: it performs worse on the metrics that matter in the existing value network (speed, simplicity, conversion rate) but enables something entirely new (customized shared-living arrangements) that the existing value network doesn't need. Per Ch 5, this is exactly why the feature must be built by 'organizations whose customers need them' — a small organization serving mid-term shared housing seekers who DO need negotiation, not a large organization serving traditional renters who see negotiation as friction.
